abstracts.cdata!:
The overall outcome of the project is
            satisfactory. The key lessons learned are: a) A flexible
            program approach has been keen to guaranteeing project
            success, as it allowed the Bank and the implementing agency
            to respond adequately to changes in rehabilitation
            priorities during project implementation. b) The appraisal
            team did not take into account the slow system in Egypt of
            awarding contracts for procurement of goods and the slow
            pace of civil work construction for pumping stations. c)
            Monitoring and evaluation capacity needs to be enhanced at
            Mechanical and Electrical Department (MED) to enable the
            tracking of project costs, benefits, and impacts. d)
            Although not part of the project, it was realized that an
            environment unit is needed at MED to monitor water and other
            related environment quality and alert authorities about
            problems for corrective action. e) In the case of new
            stations, close coordination by MED of the
            electro-mechanical equipment contracts and related civil
            work contracts is key to reducing implementation delays. f)
            There are considerable benefits to having repeater projects
            with the same implementation agency. This allows the
            building of a core professional team at MED that is familiar
            with World Bank requirements for project implementation, and
            that can save effort and time because it is well established
            and operational.
